intro: Phymatopsis subebenipes, commonly known as the Texas spiderwort, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States, particularly Texas and New Mexico. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as prairies and rocky soils. It has lance-shaped leaves and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Phymatopsis subebenipes is also known for its ability to thrive in harsh, arid environments.
